solution_line_template: First we find how many cookies Betty will eat in a week by multiplying her daily amount by {days_in_week}, meaning {days_in_week}*{cookies_per_day}=<<{cookies_eaten_week}={cookies_eaten_week}>>{cookies_eaten_week} cookies eaten in a week.
We repeat this for the brownies, finding she eats {days_in_week}*{brownies_per_day}=<<{days_in_week}*{brownies_per_day}={brownies_eaten_week}>>{brownies_eaten_week} brownies in a week.

We subtract the {cookies_eaten_week} cookies from the original amount of {initial_cookies}, finding {initial_cookies}-{cookies_eaten_week}= <<{initial_cookies}-{cookies_eaten_week}={cookies_remaining}>>{cookies_remaining} cookies remaining.
We repeat this step for the brownies, finding {initial_brownies}-{brownies_eaten_week}= <<{initial_brownies}-{brownies_eaten_week}={brownies_remaining}>>{brownies_remaining} brownies remaining.

In the end, therefore, Betty has {cookies_remaining}-{brownies_remaining}= <<{cookies_remaining}-{brownies_remaining}={difference_cookies_brownies}>>{difference_cookies_brownies} more cookies than brownies.
